availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: William Logan Clarke (Louisville, Kentucky, clerk and soldier (C.S.A.))

body.p: Louisville, Jefferson County, Kentucky, clerk and soldier. Kentucky native. Son of Charles Clarke and Jane L. Clarke. Married to Sarah Helms Clarke in Barren County, Kentucky, on December 16, 1862. Father of W.H. Clarke. Attended school in Louisville, Kentucky, in 1850. Household owned five enslaved persons in Louisville in 1850. Custom house clerk in Louisville in 1860. Owned one enslaved person in Louisville in 1860. Household owned five enslaved persons in Louisville in 1860. Served in the National Blues, Kentucky State Militia, as a first lieutenant in 1860. Served in the 6th Kentucky Volunteer Infantry Regiment (C.S.A.) as a first lieutenant and lieutenant colonel from October 7, 1861 to May 3, 1865. Wounded at the Battle of Stone's River in Rutherford County, Tennessee, in December 1862. Wounded at the Battle of New Hope Church in Paulding County, Georgia, on May 27, 1864. Hospitalized in Richmond County from May 1864 to January 1865. Signed a loyalty oath to the U. S. government on May 14, 1865.
